title: How I reverse engineered Notion API
Notion
a
https://www.notion.so/How-I-reverse-engineered-Notion-API-88aee8f43620471aa9dbcad28368174c
is a great tool for writing but the content is trapped inside the web app.

inline_content.Text: Notion
is a great tool for writing but the content is trapped inside the web app.

title: The company is working on an official API but I'm impatient.

inline_content.Text: The company is working on an official API but I'm impatient.

title: This article describes how I reverse engineered their API and created a Go library
notionapi
a
https://github.com/kjk/notionapi

inline_content.Text: This article describes how I reverse engineered their API and created a Go library
notionapi

title: It all began with a failure.

inline_content.Text: It all began with a failure.

title: My first attempt at extracting notion content was traditional web scraping.

inline_content.Text: My first attempt at extracting notion content was traditional web scraping.

title: I found a Python
script
a
https://github.com/shariq/notion-on-firebase
that uses Selenium to recursively spider a Notion page and publish it to Firebase Hosting.

inline_content.Text: I found a Python
script
that uses Selenium to recursively spider a Notion page and publish it to Firebase Hosting.

title: I ported it to Node to use
Puppeteer
a
https://www.notion.so/Advanced-web-spidering-with-Puppeteer-ea07db1b9bff415ab180b0525f3898f6
(better technology than Selenium).

inline_content.Text: I ported it to Node to use
Puppeteer
(better technology than Selenium).

title: While it worked this approach is limited to getting a verbatim HTML of the pages as they are rendered by the Notion application.

inline_content.Text: While it worked this approach is limited to getting a verbatim HTML of the pages as they are rendered by the Notion application.

title: I wanted to be able to change the look of the page, add elements like footers and headers and navigation bar.

inline_content.Text: I wanted to be able to change the look of the page, add elements like footers and headers and navigation bar.

title: I briefly considered trying to reconstruct the structure of the page from rendered HTML but at best that would be a lot of ugly guesswork.

inline_content.Text: I briefly considered trying to reconstruct the structure of the page from rendered HTML but at best that would be a lot of ugly guesswork.
The lightbulb moment

title: The way modern SPA application like Notion usually work is that they render most of the HTML on the client with JavaScript using the data they request from the server.

inline_content.Text: The way modern SPA application like Notion usually work is that they render most of the HTML on the client with JavaScript using the data they request from the server.

title: A quick trip to Chrome Dev Tools confirmed that theory.

inline_content.Text: A quick trip to Chrome Dev Tools confirmed that theory.

title: When loading a Notion page I saw XHR requests like
/api/v3/getRecordValues
c
and
/api/v3/loadPageChunk
c

inline_content.Text: When loading a Notion page I saw XHR requests like
/api/v3/getRecordValues
and
/api/v3/loadPageChunk

title: Lucky for me the API is not obfuscated. It returns responses as JSON data and it isn't hard to figure out the meaning of fields.

inline_content.Text: Lucky for me the API is not obfuscated. It returns responses as JSON data and it isn't hard to figure out the meaning of fields.

title: Instead of deducing structure from HTML I can just ask the server for the structure.

inline_content.Text: Instead of deducing structure from HTML I can just ask the server for the structure.
Building tools

title: I could have looked at API requests between client and server in Chrome dev tools but it's not the best workflow.

inline_content.Text: I could have looked at API requests between client and server in Chrome dev tools but it's not the best workflow.

title: My first step was to write node.js script that logs all XHR requests that the client invokes when rendering a given page.

inline_content.Text: My first step was to write node.js script that logs all XHR requests that the client invokes when rendering a given page.

title: That has several advantages over using dev tools:

inline_content.Text: That has several advantages over using dev tools:

title: I could filter out requests to third-party services like amplitude, fullstory and intercom

inline_content.Text: I could filter out requests to third-party services like amplitude, fullstory and intercom

title: I could filter out requests that are not interesting like
/api/v3/ping
c

inline_content.Text: I could filter out requests that are not interesting like
/api/v3/ping
I could pretty-print JSON

title: I could write captured traffic to a file for further analysis

inline_content.Text: I could write captured traffic to a file for further analysis
Here's the script:
The big picture analysis

title: After looking at captured data, the structure of Notion content is not complicated.

inline_content.Text: After looking at captured data, the structure of Notion content is not complicated.

title: Everything, including a top-level page, is a block.

inline_content.Text: Everything, including a top-level page, is a block.

title: Blocks are identified by a unique id which looks like a standard UUID format.

inline_content.Text: Blocks are identified by a unique id which looks like a standard UUID format.

title: Blocks are arranged into a tree i.e. some blocks have children.

inline_content.Text: Blocks are arranged into a tree i.e. some blocks have children.

title: Blocks have metadata, like creation time, last edit time, version etc.

inline_content.Text: Blocks have metadata, like creation time, last edit time, version etc.

title: There are different kinds of blocks: a page, text, todo item, list item etc.

inline_content.Text: There are different kinds of blocks: a page, text, todo item, list item etc.

title: Some blocks have properties specific to that block type. For example a page block has
title
c
property.

inline_content.Text: Some blocks have properties specific to that block type. For example a page block has
title
property.

title: To get the content of a page we start with its UUID which we can find out because it's last part of the url of the page.

inline_content.Text: To get the content of a page we start with its UUID which we can find out because it's last part of the url of the page.

title: We can issue
/api/v3/getRecordValues
c
API to get list of blocks in the page and then
/api/v3/loadPageChunk
c
to get content of those blocks.

inline_content.Text: We can issue
/api/v3/getRecordValues
API to get list of blocks in the page and then
/api/v3/loadPageChunk
to get content of those blocks.

title: The rest of the work is figuring out what kinds of blocks there are, how are they represented and writing some code to help in retrieving the data and presenting it in a format that is easier to consume for the purpose of generating output e.g. a customized HTML.

inline_content.Text: The rest of the work is figuring out what kinds of blocks there are, how are they represented and writing some code to help in retrieving the data and presenting it in a format that is easier to consume for the purpose of generating output e.g. a customized HTML.
Testing different kinds of blocks

title: Notion page consist of different kinds of blocks and we need to know how each block is represented in JSON response.

inline_content.Text: Notion page consist of different kinds of blocks and we need to know how each block is represented in JSON response.

title: To investigate it systematically, I've created a test page for each kind of block and used the request logging script to look at JSON returned by the server for that block.

inline_content.Text: To investigate it systematically, I've created a test page for each kind of block and used the request logging script to look at JSON returned by the server for that block.
Writing Go library

title: Next step was writing a Go library.

inline_content.Text: Next step was writing a Go library.

title: Having capture sample JSON responses from
getRecordValues
c
and
loadPageChunk
c
I used
Quicktype
a
https://app.quicktype.io/
to generate Go structures.

inline_content.Text: Having capture sample JSON responses from
getRecordValues
and
loadPageChunk
I used
Quicktype
to generate Go structures.

title: I had to tweak them a bit to accommodate response variations.

inline_content.Text: I had to tweak them a bit to accommodate response variations.

title: The rest of the effort was writing a helper function that abstracts the details of HTTP requests and returns an easy to use struct describing a notion page.

inline_content.Text: The rest of the effort was writing a helper function that abstracts the details of HTTP requests and returns an easy to use struct describing a notion page.

title: There result of that work is
notionapi
a
https://github.com/kjk/notionapi
Go package.

inline_content.Text: There result of that work is
notionapi
Go package.
Using the library in practice

title: This was not just an academic exercise.

inline_content.Text: This was not just an academic exercise.

title: This blog was powered by markdown files I stored in GitHub repository.

inline_content.Text: This blog was powered by markdown files I stored in GitHub repository.

title: My goal was to move the content to Notion, so that I can edit it more easily, convert it to HTML and publish as my website/blog.

inline_content.Text: My goal was to move the content to Notion, so that I can edit it more easily, convert it to HTML and publish as my website/blog.
You can see the code
here

inline_content.Text: The high-level structure of the code:

title: I use my Go
notionapi
a
https://github.com/kjk/notionapi
library to download the content from Notion

inline_content.Text: I use my Go
notionapi
library to download the content from Notion

title: I cache downloaded data and store them in git repository. This is to make sure I have a copy of data even if Notion disappears, to make it faster to tweak publishing code (no need to re-download) and to be nicer to Notion server (no re-downloads unless I absolutely have to)

inline_content.Text: I cache downloaded data and store them in git repository. This is to make sure I have a copy of data even if Notion disappears, to make it faster to tweak publishing code (no need to re-download) and to be nicer to Notion server (no re-downloads unless I absolutely have to)

title: I convert Notion data to HTML, wrap it in templates for my pages and write HTML files to disk

inline_content.Text: I convert Notion data to HTML, wrap it in templates for my pages and write HTML files to disk
I deploy to
Netlify
